title: Reframing Relationship with Death
content: A hospice and palliative care specialist discusses how his own brush with death radically shifted his perspective and ultimately forged his path towards palliative care and helping patients integrate and understand their life in a meaningful way. He recounts several moving stories from his patients, which reveal important lessons about overcoming the fear of death, letting go of regret, and what’s most important in life. He discusses the major design flaws of a “death phobic” healthcare system. Furthermore, he makes the case that seeing death as a part of life allows us to live well, as opposed to living to evade death itself. He concludes with a discussion around physician-assisted death as well as his hopes around the use of psychedelics to reduce suffering in end-of-life care.

title: Physical Pain and Emotional Struggles
content: A release of the physical pain: “I had just been literally gritting my teeth and trying to feel or act as strong”. Shame and embarrassment: The sorrow came a bit from embarrassment for doing this and putting his parents through so much pain. Fear of going through life disabled: would ever have sex again, what women were going to think of me, what my friends would think of me, he has seen the cruelty towards diabled people before.

title: Recovery and Search for Meaning
content: While in recovery, it was “like a torture chamber interspersed with incredible boredom”. He spent a lot of time pondering questions of meaning and identity in a way that was very relevant and therapeutic and practical: “What am I now? Am I less of a person? Do I have less to offer the world?” He was looking for meaning-making—i.e., how humans work with pain, how did humans work with things they can’t control.

title: Acceptance of New Body and Mental Health
content: After his injuries, he almost felt more comfortable in his new body— “I got the body that much more mirrored how I felt inside; fragmented, broken, confused, unintegrated, different.” This mental process of accepting his new body, that it was the “right” body for him, really removed the sense of regret and second guessing he otherwise would’ve felt.

title: Impact of Sister's Suicide on Mental Health
content: After his sister’s suicide, she was diagnosed as having textbook bipolar disorder. But even leading up to her death, she had everyone fooled including his parents, and even her therapist of 10 years—“she was a master manipulator”. His sister’s death led him to consider leaving medicine—he was demoralized that he was someone who wanted to heal people and yet he completely missed his sister’s diagnosis right under his nose.

title: Discovering Palliative Care
content: Illness, disability, death are normal, they’re not anomalous. It’s not just the angle of the joint it was concerned with, but the angle of the thoughts and the way that we see ourselves. The words we choose to describe our place in the world and how we either suffer for those words or how we really can find ourselves doing something more therapeutic.

title: Difference between Palliative Care and Hospice
content: Palliative care is simply the interdisciplinary pursuit of the quality of life. Within the context of serious illness palliative care is that mode of care which helps you feel as well as possible—Emotionally, physically, spiritually. There is nothing in the definition of palliative care that makes it that you need be dying anytime soon—Death is included in this, but it’s not the focus. The thing that we treat in palliative care is suffering, not disease. Hospice is a subset of palliative care—it is essentially palliative care that’s applied at the end of life.

title: Our Complicated Relationship with Death
content: Even though all of us are going to die, it seems we don’t live like that is a reality. We are almost in denial, or just have an inability to look at death. We are wired to run away from death. We’re also the only species who is aware of our own eventual mortality. It’s quite a predicament we humans have, it’s a huge subject for us to wrap our heads around.

title: Fear of Death
content: Many of his patient present with a fear of death, but there’s an important distinction—Are you afraid of the dying process? Or are you afraid of being dead? In the former, there are medications to help the body come down for a “gentle landing” (i.e., not suffer in physical pain). So if that’s your fear, he offers his patients reassurance. If you fear is about being dead – what happens next, leaving your family behind, missing out, etc. In this case, there is no clear “answer”. But “as a fellow traveler, I can accompany you there. We can think about that together. We can talk about it and then we can make a life that responds to that big question.”

title: Importance of Palliative Care
content: Palliative care should really begin much earlier in life. Whether actually a palliative care referral or a palliative care mindset, but one way or another finding our way into this subject while we’ve got plenty of road in front of us, is absolutely the right, best way. Given that 100% of patients die eventually, you’d think that palliative care would not need to be a specialty, it would be baked into how all of medicine works.

title: Flaws of Healthcare System
content: The overarching design flaw is that the system is focused on disease, not on the people dealing with disease. The second you make it about the person living with the disease, not the disease itself, you welcome in all sorts of things into the mix beyond just their physiology and anatomy: Their social, emotional, and spiritual lives. This can help with doctor burnout. It also helps with the expectation management—doctors can not be expected to work miracles.

title: Regrets and Insights from Patients in Final Moments
content: Common regrets from hospice patients include wishing they had spent more time with family than at work, wishing they had dared to love more, wishing they hadn’t been so afraid, and wishing they had just let themselves be themselves. The commonality is that they wish they had let themselves come to terms with death earlier in their lives, because it would have changed the decisions they made.

title: Physician-Assisted Dying
content: Physician-assisted dying (aka euthanasia) has been legalized in a handful of states. The process includes writing a letter for approval, there’s a 2 week wait, you have to have two physicians involved, etc. This is in place as a fail safe so that people don’t do something in a moment of weakness. For some people, it is exactly the right decision—but only when it is seen as a meaningful response, not a flight from suffering, but a moving towards something meaningful.

title: Therapeutic Use of Psychedelics
content: Psilocybin has been shown to help with depression in patients with cancer. MDMA is currently being used to treat PTSD. Ketamine is also proving to be a therapeutic for depression.

title: Psychedelics in End of Life Care
content: These same substances are being researched for anxieties around the fears of death in a patient population dealing with terminal illness or serious illness. People who are gripped by a fear of death, gripped by a sense of meaninglessness and not belonging and not feeling connected come out of one sessions losing their fear of death, feeling part of something larger than themselves, having a totally different relationship to fear. The effect lasts for a months suggesting it’s not just an acute chemical response.

title: Interdisciplinary Approach to Health
content: Physicians can partner with architects and artists, designers, and other disciplines. Or even death doulas and quasi medical folks and the alternative and integrative medicine folks. All of a sudden, we are part of a much larger family working on behalf of something much larger than even medicine.

title: Perspective on Death and Medicine
content: Death has become a medical issue. It doesn’t belong there. Suffering and death are way bigger than medicine. Medicine doesn’t have to carry all that water by itself. People are going to start taking care of people and not handing themselves over to doctors to do the trick.
